title-group.article-title: The Lived Experience of Anxiety Among Late Adolescents During High School
title-group.subtitle: An Interpretive Phenomenological Inquiry

p.bold: American Holistic Nurses Association Education Provider Committee

p.italic: Journal of Holistic Nursing Continuing Education Activity #654

p.bold: Get instant contact hours by completing your CNE online at www.ahna.org!

list-item.p: Read the corresponding article in the September 2013 issue of the Journal of Holistic Nursing (Vol. 31, No. 3).
Go to www.ahna.org/ShopCNE to purchase the online continuing education activity.
Go to www.ahna.org and click on Education > Earn Contact Hours to access the Journal of Holistic Nursing Online CNE.
This CNE activity is valid through August 31, 2015.

sec.title: Successful Completion Requirements to Receive a Certificate for 4.1 Contact Hours
sec.p: Requirements for successful completion: 70% or better score on posttest and completion of online evaluation.

sec.title: Purpose and Learning Objectives
sec.p: To Enable the learner to explore the experience of anxiety in late adolescents and utilize this knowledge to develop holistic strategies designed to support resilience, stress management and coping within this population
Upon completion of this educational activity, the participant will be able to:

list-item.p: Describe the importance of understanding the experience of anxiety in late adolescence
Identify the current knowledge gap in examining anxiety in late adolescents
Review Merleau-Ponty’s interpretive phenomenological methodology
Examine the application of Merleau-Ponty’s interpretive phenomenological methodology in a study of anxiety in late adolescents
Explore the three main themes and seven subthemes discovered as a result of this study
Describe the meaning of anxiety in late adolescents as an embodied experience
Apply the results of this study in the development of two activities designed to support resilience, stress management and coping within this population

p.bold: American Holistic Nurses Association Education Provider Committee

p.italic: Journal of Holistic Nursing Continuing Education Activity #654
“The Lived Experience of Anxiety Among Late Adolescents During High School: An Interpretive Phenomenological Inquiry”

list-item.p:
Altshuler and Ruble examined developmental changes in children’s abilities to cope with uncontrollable stress and found that as children age their coping strategies:
Become more behavioral distraction and less cognitive distraction
Do not change at all
Became more and more prevalent and sophisticated
Shift from screaming and crying to hitting and running away

Adolescents aged 14 to 17 years reported the stressors that were most upsetting to them included:
School, TV news reports, losing at sporting events, and parents
Friends, Significant others, obesity and school
School, parents, friends and significant others
Parents, world violence/war, friends and school

In response to the identified knowledge gap in examining anxiety in late adolescents, the current study is designed to:
identify more specific risk factors for adolescents anxiety
develop evidenced-based tools for assessing anxiety in adolescents
study depression and low self-esteem in adolescents
gain an understanding of the lived experience of everyday anxiety among late adolescents

Ensuring the confidentiality, safety, and well-being of participants is accomplished by the researcher obtaining:
signed consent from each participant
signed consent from participant and parent
IRB (Institutional Review Board) approval
signed consent from participant and school officials

In this study anxiety is defined as participants who experienced:
full criteria of symptoms for clinical diagnosis of anxiety
daily symptoms of anxiety, e.g.: hyper vigilance, impaired concentration, and avoidance
occasional anxiety symptoms, e.g.: hyper vigilance, impaired concentration, and dread
daily symptoms of hyperarousal, suicide and or intent to harm self

“Member checks” required the researcher to ascertain the credibility of data analysis by obtaining ongoing feedback from:
another researcher
members of the thesis committee
half of the participants
each of the participants

The embodied experience of anxiety in late adolescents in school included:
social isolation and parental support
peer pressure and dating
performance stress and bullying
unsupportive peers and parents

In this study the adolescent participants reported that over time their anxiety:
was influenced by their parents
decreased when entering college
decreased with counseling
was an experience they felt better about

The holistic school nurse receives a referral to see a female senior student who is experiencing increased signs of anxiety and exhibits ineffective coping skills. The nurse is aware that in this population anxiety is often related to:
hormonal changes
social and family pressures
changing body image
ineffective sleep patterns

Nurse Practitioners provide holistic care for adolescents expressing everyday anxiety by focusing on healing interventions which would include all of the following except:
mindfulness and meditation
yoga
peer socialization
breathing and relaxation
